error.signature: SSL: unsupported protocol / TLS version not supported

verdict.summary: The client or server attempted to use a deprecated TLS version (TLS 1.0 or 1.1) that the other party no longer supports. OpenSSL 3.x disables TLS 1.0 and 1.1 by default due to known security vulnerabilities.

dead_ends.action: Re-enable TLS 1.0/1.1 in the system-wide OpenSSL configuration
dead_ends.why_fails: TLS 1.0 and 1.1 have known vulnerabilities (BEAST, POODLE downgrade). Re-enabling them system-wide affects all applications and introduces security risks. Compliance standards (PCI DSS, HIPAA) prohibit TLS 1.0/1.1, making this a non-starter for regulated environments.

dead_ends.action: Compile OpenSSL from source with legacy protocol support forced on
dead_ends.why_fails: Building a custom OpenSSL with re-enabled legacy protocols creates a maintenance burden, breaks system package management, and may introduce build-time errors. Other applications linking against the system OpenSSL will not benefit, and the custom build must be manually patched for future vulnerabilities.

workarounds.action: Upgrade the legacy server or client to support TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3
workarounds.how:
1. Identify which side requires the legacy protocol: openssl s_client -connect host:443 -tls1_2 (if this works, the server supports 1.2)
2. Update the legacy application or its TLS library
3. Configure TLS 1.2 minimum: ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3; in nginx
4. For Java apps, ensure JDK 8u261+ and set -Dhttps.protocols=TLSv1.2,TLSv1.3
5. Test: openssl s_client -connect host:443 -tls1_2

workarounds.action: Use a TLS-terminating reverse proxy to bridge protocol versions
workarounds.how:
1. Deploy a reverse proxy (nginx, HAProxy) in front of the legacy server
2. Configure the proxy to accept TLS 1.2/1.3 from clients
3. Configure the proxy backend to speak the legacy protocol to the old server (on a trusted internal network)
4. Example nginx config:
   upstream legacy { server legacy-host:443; }
   server { listen 443 ssl; ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3; proxy_pass https://legacy; proxy_ssl_protocols TLSv1; }
5. This isolates the legacy protocol to a controlled internal segment

leads_to.condition: when forcing a TLS version that the server supports but with incompatible cipher suites
when the server immediately drops connections using unsupported protocol versions

preceded_by.condition: when a generic handshake failure is narrowed down to a TLS version issue
when updating OpenSSL to fix CA issues also raises the minimum TLS version

frequently_confused_with.distinction: TLS version unsupported is specifically about protocol version negotiation; protocol error covers broader handshake failures including cipher and extension mismatches
TLS version errors occur during SSL negotiation after TCP connects; connection refused means TCP itself never established
